## Loading the MitoPilot package

To load the MitoPilot R package, we first need to modify our `PATH` environmental variable. This will allow our RStudio session to find several important programs, including `java`, `nextflow`, and `qsub`.

```{R eval=F}
# modify PATH to include:
#   ~/bin (contains nextflow exe)
#   java 21.0.2 (required for nextflow)
#   qsub (required for nextflow to submit jobs)  
default_path <- "/usr/local/sbin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/sbin:/usr/bin:/usr/lib/rstudio-server/bin/quarto/bin:/usr/lib/rstudio-server/bin/postback"
new_path <- paste0(Sys.getenv("HOME"), "/bin:/share/apps/tools/java/21.0.2/bin:/cm/shared/apps/uge/8.8.1/bin/lx-amd64/")
Sys.setenv(PATH = paste(new_path, default_path, sep = ":"))
```

Next, load the MitoPilot package. 
```{R eval=F}
library(MitoPilot)
```

You should see a message confirming that Nextflow is installed and accessible.
```
Welcome to {MitoPilot}!
Using Nextflow version 24.10.4 build 5934
```

You can now utilize all of MitoPilot's functions, such as [initializing a project](https://smithsonian.github.io/MitoPilot/#initializing-a-project) or [opening the R Shiny GUI](https://smithsonian.github.io/MitoPilot/#running-the-pipeline). 

We're now ready to start the [example project](/qmd/example_project/01_init.qmd)!
